Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Chian Grand Style pottery chalice; cream slip; interior glazed black with traces of rosette in added red and white; exterior: two bands at top (fired reddish-brown) bands; painted decoration consisting of two probably facing figures (of leftmost figure, part of himation with short diagonal strokes on border remaining; of rightmost female figure, part of face and hand holding out a phiale or bowl).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Although very little of the rightmost figure remains, the flesh on Chian female figures was normally depicted in outline without any flesh colouring.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 34, no. 44, pl. XVII)
Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (p. 58, pl. VI, no. 3)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 280, no. 776, pl. 102)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0825) (phase 2)
